newsitem.title: USA: Spyglass in more software licensing talks.
newsitem.headline: Spyglass in more software licensing talks.

text.p: Spyglass Inc said Wednesday it is in talks with with various industrial and commercial companies interested in using the company's software to link their products to the World Wide Web.

"While consumer electronics applications are highly visible, significant opportunities exist for us on the industrial and commercial side," chief executive Doug Colbeth said in a statement. "We are in discussions with a number of companies in these areas who are interested in adding Web functionality to their products and services."
Spyglass on Wednesday reported fiscal second quarter earnings of $0.16 a share including an $8 million one-time payment from Microsoft Corp, versus $0.06 a share last year.

Spyglass said it has made "significant progress" in entering the Internet device market. Late last year Spyglass said it was implementing a company strategy to develop software and services to help companies connect everyday devices such as cell phones and industrial equipment to the Internet.
Colbeth noted, however, the market is a young and needs to be cultivated.

"We are the only company providing a comprehensive set of solutions allowing us to capture important design wins now that will pay off as our customers' products are widely deployed in the future," Colbeth said. "However, in the short term this remains a very new market which is going to take time for us and our partners to develop."

Spyglass said Tim Krauskopf, a founder of Spyglass, has decided to leave the company as a full-time employee to pursue additional academic credentials. He will continue as a member of the board of directors.
